This project covers a series of my work, ranging from fundermentals of covariate shift distributionally robust learning, to its integration to real-world safe exploration and domain adaption tasks.
Distributionally robust learning involves a minimax game between a predictor and an adversary, who is usually subject to constraints from data.

title: Distributionally Robust Learning under Distribution Shift

content:
This project is a collaboration between machine learning researchers and social scientists. It is a joint effort by a group of undergraduates, graduate students, postdocs, and professors. Meet our team members here!
We aim to use AI techniques for building a more trustworthy social media. We work on online trolling detection, public discussion monitoring, social network analysis, and so on. Our research asks: what a healthier public communication environment would be like in this era? And how can machine learning help?
Here are some featured projects:
 Understanding the prominent #metoo movement: What are people talking about and how are different topics discussed?    * Finding Social Media Trolls: Dynamic Keyword Selection Methods for Rapidly-Evolving Online Debates. In Neurips workshp: AI for Social Good, 2019.
  * Tracking Social Media Movements with Dynamic Keyword Algorithm. In American Political Science Association Annal Meeting and Exhibition, 2020.
  * Understanding the Evolution of the #MeToo Movement Over Time Using Topic Models. In ICML WIML Un-Workshop, 2020.
Contributors:Maya Srikanth, Sara Kangaslahti, Nicholas Adams-Cohen, Jian Cao, Jean Kossaifi, Mike Alvarez, and Anima Anandkumar.

title: Trustworthy Social Media
